data.text: Bicycle Touring Without a Phone/Smartphone
How many travel without a cell/smart phone today since they have only been around for about 20 or so years? Any old timers still traveling without one? Let us know about your experience.

I can travel without one, In some countries you need it to pay stuff (China), while in some part of the world they donâ€™t even have cabled telephone let alone a cellphone, the cellphone would be next to useless in those area.

data.text: where? in most 3rd world countries they have smartphone, never really did cable, went directly to mobile / wireless tec, as its much easier and cheaper than cable.

data.text: I spent 12 days in Southern Andes without cellphone network. Not once but a few times.

data.text: I have always adopted new tech as soon as I was able to see its value. A smart phone of any generation is an essential element, especially for us wanderers.
data.author: Tom Iarossi

data.text: I'm just thinking about completely disconnecting from the world on my next trip. No tracking, no stats, no mapping, no connection. Wonder how that would feel? Would it be better, or worse?
data.author: Andy Jackson

data.text: I carry a phone but it's either off or playing Spotify .... never used Strava or anything like that ... I have an old school handlebar mounted map case I got free from MBR in the 90s .... I find tech takes up way too much headspace to make it an integral part of my riding .... but it's good to have a phone on you for emergencies somewhere in your kit and if it's off you're not fretting about battery life
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: I used to travel without one when I was young and had a lot of time. Now I can't afford it, even though I'd love to, because everything just takes longer without one and I can't be away from work for 3 whole months like when I was still at university.
data.author: Salvu Agius

data.text: A smart phone is an enabler. You can keep it switched off, but it will help you when you need rescuing, a place to sleep, or route guidance. Or to take a selfie.
data.author: Marnus Hattingh

data.text: Smartphones save space and a huge amount of time. It's also the only source of entertainment I have in my tent besides sleeping

data.text: , I haven't owned any mobile phone for the past 18 months. Previous to that I had a basic one that I could send texts or make calls from - but didn't once use it when travelling for the previous 8 years. During that time I have cycled in at least ten countries. I carry paper maps, visit information centres and stop to ask for directions or local knowledge from random people along the way. I still send postcards home, but notice that it is getting harder to find those in some countries - or somewhere to buy stamps. :-)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: We used to tour without because they didnâ€™t exist. Paper maps and road signs for navigation. Now we have bike computers (so we can record where weâ€™ve been and have a route prepared so we donâ€™t need to stop at every intersection). We also have our phones which we could do without, but why? It makes it a lot easier to book places to stay (or just find them) and check the weather, for example. Another benefit is when you get separated from your partner. This happened to us (1991?) and although I canâ€™t remember exactly which year, I do remember the fear of not knowing where he wasâ€”ahead or behindâ€”and he had the same fears. It was a remote areaâ€¦ Phones would have made it so much easier, if, of course, there was service. Remote parts of BC still donâ€™t have reliable cell reception.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: Speaking as a full time Traveller (sometimes but not always by bicycle) I think that the developed world is now geared up to assume that everyone has access at least to the internet if not a smartphone and trying to navigate through life without one is just making life difficult for yourself. Sure stay away from Facebook, Strava etc, use paper maps (my favorite read) don't interact with friends or family via WhatsApp. But my bet is that sooner or later a situation will arise where you realise the stupidity of trying to step back 20 years.
data.author: Nev Chamberlain

data.text: I don't own a cellphone. I do have an ipod touch w/wifi. Most places have wifi.
data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: I plan routes in advance on Ride w/GPS and download them for offline. I write down the routes on index cards and have a cue clip on my handlebars. I write out each turn and can get 85 miles on one card. I look at satellite and street view in advance to make sure I don't miss a turn. The other person usually has one in case of emergency.
data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: Tours in 1992-94, 1999-2000, 2006-07, 2015-2017, finally beginning of 2021we finally got a cell phone that we use as a landline and took it on our northern tier route but sometimes we forgot we were caring it.
